channel.title: Contact Lenses
channel.description:
I just got my trial pair, and when I'm done with these I'll go back and pick up what I need for 6 months. I'm new to contacts, and had a hell of a time trying to get them in/out.
Anyone have any tips for them or good/terrible experiences that they'd like to share? :P

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Tico135, post:1, topic:283077”]I just got my trial pair, and when I’m done with these I’ll go back and pick up what I need for 6 months. I’m new to contacts, and had a hell of a time trying to get them in/out.

Anyone have any tips for them or good/terrible experiences that they’d like to share? :P[/quote]

Its hard at first but it gets easier.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Lothy:

Are they pretty easy to keep clean?

There a two types I know about, day lenses, and month lenses.
Day lenses you just take on a new one every day and no cleaning, month lenses like 93dcthugs93 said.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @93dcthugs93 93dcthugs93
item.description:
@93dcthugs93 wrote:

Very. All you do is take each lens one by one, and put it in your hand and squirt some of the cleaner on to it or whatever it’s called. Rub it around a little bit and you’re done.

When you take them out put them in their case and squirt the cleaner in there and leave them like that until you want to put them in again, and keep changing the cleaner every time.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Are they pretty easy to keep clean?

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @93dcthugs93 93dcthugs93
item.description:
@93dcthugs93 wrote:

I’ve had contact lenses for about… 6 or 7 months now?
They’re difficult to get in/out and deal with for the first few weeks but you’ll get used to them fast and realize how much of a convenience they really are

With contacts I see better than 20/20.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @Uriko Uriko
item.description:

http://www.1-save-on-lens.com/cgi/saveonlens.cgi?d=gothika_GreenCat&id=11zKew07vwmF2

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @Man_UTD_Freak Man UTD Freak
item.description:
@Man_UTD_Freak wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:18, topic:283077”][quote author=SomethingToHide link=topic=374069.msg2821666#msg2821666 date=1244652097]

I’m really fucking colorblind.

The only one I got right on the thing was the first one, which was the black/white control test.
[/quote]

What test did you do??
I thought there was only one standard test? You must identify the number from an array of coloured dots.
When I took it the “female” opticians could see a completly different number to me :s


I can make out 22?[/quote]

I did the same optical test but it seemed fairly easier than that. Is there really a number in there because I cannot tell at all?

Anyway I have been wearing glasses for ages and I was wondering (on average) roughly how expensive contacts are. I’m in need for contacts as I do play quite a few sports such as Football (Soccer) + Cricket (You Americans may not know that one).

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Yeah didn’t mean to worry anyone or anything, T4_ is totally right, I have no idea if its even happened to anyone. Just saying, it’s not biologically impossible

EDIT: And cuz I’m worrying I’ll put some dude off contacts now, even if it were possible, Streptococcus pyogenes and the other shit that causes TSS is everywhere anyway, so it’d be no more likely than the chance of you getting TSS from a cut or burn or w/e

Do contacts kids

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:29, topic:283077”]I would imagine its possible to get Toxic Shock Syndrome from contact lenses, since you can get it through the skin.

It’d be incredibly incredibly fucking rare though, it’s rare enough to get it from tampons and contact lenses are stored in saline.[/quote]
Never heard of toxic shock from these; as long as you don’t put a dirty contact in your eye or leave it in for days, you’re fine.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @cumescape cumescape
item.description:
@cumescape wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:4, topic:283077”][quote author=SomethingToHide link=topic=374069.msg2821166#msg2821166 date=1244604131]
But that’s just because I put them in at 4:30AM and don’t get to take them out until 12AM.
[/quote]
Wont you go into shock or something or is that just tampons?[/quote]
only tampons lol

[quote=“haticks, post:5, topic:283077”]Ive had the same contacts in for like 3 months, and they don’t bother me at all. Protip: only pull down the botom eye lid, makes it way easier.[/quote]Your going to have even fucked up eyes

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Make sure you get good quality drops/solution or your eyes can itch.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @goatee goatee
item.description:
@goatee wrote:

[quote=“Bebe, post:25, topic:283077”]You’ll get used to taking them in and out eventually. It took me about 4 weeks of use before I could put contacts in and out without problems.

What’s the difference between ‘dailies’ and ‘monthlies’? Are monthly contacts actually designed to be left in the eye while sleeping or something? Or is the real difference in pricing? It’d be great if someone could explain this.

The difference in pricing is big enough to make people say no to dailies and yes to monthlies. Monthlies are designed better, and I’d imagine they are more durable. And of course the final difference being that you discard dailies after each day, and monthlies after each month. Either way, you aren’t supposed to sleep in them; if you tell your optometrist you did, they’d probably rage at you.

Just took them out after about 8 hours of wearing them; I found it pretty easy to do so. Hopefully it’ll take me less time tomorrow then it did this morning.

You can get “Night & Day” contacts that you can sleep in. I have them[/quote]
Wow really? Are they dailies or monthlies?

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @Bebemycat2 Bebe
item.description:
@Bebemycat2 wrote:

You’ll get used to taking them in and out eventually. It took me about 4 weeks of use before I could put contacts in and out without problems.

[quote=“Tico135, post:24, topic:283077”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=374069.msg2821620#msg2821620 date=1244649586]
What’s the difference between ‘dailies’ and ‘monthlies’? Are monthly contacts actually designed to be left in the eye while sleeping or something? Or is the real difference in pricing? It’d be great if someone could explain this.
[/quote]

The difference in pricing is big enough to make people say no to dailies and yes to monthlies. Monthlies are designed better, and I’d imagine they are more durable. And of course the final difference being that you discard dailies after each day, and monthlies after each month. Either way, you aren’t supposed to sleep in them; if you tell your optometrist you did, they’d probably rage at you.

Just took them out after about 8 hours of wearing them; I found it pretty easy to do so. Hopefully it’ll take me less time tomorrow then it did this morning. :P[/quote]
You can get “Night & Day” contacts that you can sleep in. I have them

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

Lothy:

What’s the difference between ‘dailies’ and ‘monthlies’? Are monthly contacts actually designed to be left in the eye while sleeping or something? Or is the real difference in pricing? It’d be great if someone could explain this.

The difference in pricing is big enough to make people say no to dailies and yes to monthlies. Monthlies are designed better, and I’d imagine they are more durable. And of course the final difference being that you discard dailies after each day, and monthlies after each month. Either way, you aren’t supposed to sleep in them; if you tell your optometrist you did, they’d probably rage at you.

Just took them out after about 8 hours of wearing them; I found it pretty easy to do so. Hopefully it’ll take me less time tomorrow then it did this morning.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @maniown maniown
item.description:
@maniown wrote:

I have wore contacts since the 6th grade. Only problems i have now is when i go to a friends house and sleep in them. Epic dryness in the mornings.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

That was the test. The first one in the book is plain black/white, everyone can see the numbers or there is something else wrong with you. The control.

The rest are colors. I got none of the rest right.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @goatee goatee
item.description:
@goatee wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:15, topic:283077”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=374069.msg2821620#msg2821620 date=1244649586]
I wouldn’t mind giving contacts a try myself. I currently use glasses for short sightedness (with my right eye being reasonably weaker than my left).
[/quote]

I am exactly the same. I am like 1.5 on my left and 1.75 on my right. I wear them while watching TV and looking at a board far away. I am “supposed” to wear them when looking at computer screen but I do not find the point when I can clearly see it properly and in fact glasses make my eyes hurt when looking at a monitor.

Slightly off-topic but has anyone taken the colour-blindness test? I have taken it and I have been confirmed slightly colour-blind which stops me bring a pilot Its actualy pretty common in males.[/quote]

And stops you being a sniper :P, actually you can’t be a sniper even if you have laser eye surgery for some wierd reason.

Both of my eyes are short sighted so whenever I go outside with lenses on everything looks so crisp and sharp and it’s great. I’m glad I got lenses because glasses really aren’t my thing, aso lenses are great for playing sports because the only time they could come out are if you got hit in the eye by a fist or a football, whereas glasses can get broken and get dirty so you have to keep wiping them.

[quote=“Lothy, post:13, topic:283077”]I wouldn’t mind giving contacts a try myself. I currently use glasses for short sightedness (with my right eye being reasonably weaker than my left).

What’s the difference between ‘dailies’ and ‘monthlies’? Are monthly contacts actually designed to be left in the eye while sleeping or something? Or is the real difference in pricing? It’d be great if someone could explain this.[/quote]

I definitely suggest getting lenses as they are so convenient, also I get monthlys because for my left eye I need aspheric lenses which, because I have an uncommon stigmatism in my left eye, can only be prescribed monthly. I think dailys are better though if you can get them.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Lothy:

I wouldn’t mind giving contacts a try myself. I currently use glasses for short sightedness (with my right eye being reasonably weaker than my left).

I am exactly the same. I am like 1.5 on my left and 1.75 on my right. I wear them while watching TV and looking at a board far away. I am “supposed” to wear them when looking at computer screen but I do not find the point when I can clearly see it properly and in fact glasses make my eyes hurt when looking at a monitor.

Slightly off-topic but has anyone taken the colour-blindness test? I have taken it and I have been confirmed slightly colour-blind which stops me bring a pilot Its actualy pretty common in males.

Read full topic

item.title: Contact Lenses
item.dc:creator: @PeterMan PeterMan
item.description:
@PeterMan wrote:

[quote=“Tico135, post:11, topic:283077”]Prescription is at 2.25 for distance.

Had a little bit of trouble this morning, one of them kept moving on my eye, so I had to take it out and put it back in in the middle of class. They’re pretty good now though. I’ve noticed everything is sooo trippy; normally I don’t wear my glasses everywhere, but wearing contacts everywhere makes you see the world a whole new way. :P[/quote]
It will be easier after a while, had that problem in the start as well. I have been using them for about 1 and a half year now I think, or even 2 years.

My prescription started at 1.5 I think, but it only got worse and worse and suddenly I’m on 5.75
They say it’s quite common for someone my age and that it will get better when I get older.

Read full topic
